Variables
SharpNeat.​Experiments.​ConfigModels
namespace SharpNeat.Experiments.ConfigModels
ExperimentConfig
public record
ExperimentConfig
GenerativeFnRegressionExperimentConfig
PreyCaptureExperimentConfig

Model type for NEAT experiment configuration.

Properties
Id
public string? Id { get; init }

A unique human-readable ID associated with the experiment.

Name
public string? Name { get; init }

Experiment name.

Description
public string? Description { get; init }

Experiment description.

IsAcyclic
public bool? IsAcyclic { get; init }

A boolean flag that indicates if the genomes that are evolved are acyclic, i.e. they should have no recurrent/cyclic connection paths.

CyclesPerActivation
public int? CyclesPerActivation { get; init }

For cyclic neural networks (i.e. if IsAcyclic is false) this defines how many timesteps to run the neural net per call to Activate().

ActivationFnName
public string? ActivationFnName { get; init }

Name of the neuron activation function to use in evolved networks.

EvolutionAlgorithm
public NeatEvolutionAlgorithmConfig? EvolutionAlgorithm { get; init }

NEAT evolution algorithm configuration.

ReproductionAsexual
public NeatReproductionAsexualConfig? ReproductionAsexual { get; init }

NEAT asexual reproduction configuration.

ReproductionSexual
public NeatReproductionSexualConfig? ReproductionSexual { get; init }

NEAT sexual reproduction configuration.

PopulationSize
public int? PopulationSize { get; init }

The population size to use for the experiment.

InitialInterconnectionsProportion
public double? InitialInterconnectionsProportion { get; init }

The initial interconnections proportion. This is the proportion of possible direct connections from the input nodes to the output nodes that are to be created in each initial/seed genome. The connections to create are selected at random (using a select-without-replacement method).

ConnectionWeightScale
public double? ConnectionWeightScale { get; init }

The maximum connection weight scale/magnitude.  E.g. a value of 5 defines a weight range of -5 to 5.  The weight range is strictly enforced, e.g. when creating new connections and mutating existing ones.

ComplexityRegulationStrategy
public ComplexityRegulationStrategyConfig? ComplexityRegulationStrategy { get; init }

Complexity regulation strategy configuration.

DegreeOfParallelism
public int? DegreeOfParallelism { get; init }

The number of CPU threads to distribute work to.  Set to -1 to use a thread count that matches the number of logical CPU cores.

EnableHardwareAcceleratedNeuralNets
public bool? EnableHardwareAcceleratedNeuralNets { get; init }

Enable use of hardware accelerated neural network implementations, i.e. alternative implementations that use CPU SIMD/vector instructions.

The vectorized code is provided by alternative classes, and these classes tend to be more complex than their 'baseline' non-vectorized equivalents. Therefore when debugging a problem it is often useful to disable use of all vectorized code in order to rule out that code as the source of a problem/bug.  Furthermore, enabling hardware acceleration has been observed to often result in slower execution speed, probably because NEAT deals with non-homogeneous, irregular neural network structures that are generally not conducive to the application of vectorized code.

EnableHardwareAcceleratedActivationFunctions
public bool? EnableHardwareAcceleratedActivationFunctions { get; init }

Enable use of hardware accelerated neural network activation functions, i.e. alternative implementations that use CPU SIMD/vector instructions.

The vectorized code is provided by alternative classes, and these classes tend to be more complex than their 'baseline' non-vectorized equivalents. Therefore when debugging a problem it is often useful to disable use of all vectorized code in order to rule out that code as the source of a problem/bug.  Furthermore, enabling hardware acceleration has been observed to often result in slower execution speed, probably because NEAT deals with non-homogeneous, irregular neural network structures that are generally not conducive to the application of vectorized code.
